## Creating Variables in R

Variables in R are used to store data that can be referenced and manipulated throughout your code. Here's how to create and work with variables:

### Basic Assignment




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Using the assignment operator (<-)
x <- 10
y <- "Hello, R!"
z <- TRUE

# Print the variables
x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 10
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Hello, R!"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
z
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::
:::




### Alternative Assignment Methods




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Using the equals sign (=)
age = 25

# Using the assignment operator in reverse (->)
"Data Scientist" -> job_title

# Print the variables
age
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 25
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
job_title
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Data Scientist"
```


:::
:::




### Variable Naming Rules

-   Names can contain letters, numbers, dots (.) and underscores (\_)
-   Names must start with a letter or a dot
-   If a name starts with a dot, it cannot be followed by a number
-   Names are case-sensitive (`Value` and `value` are different variables)




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Valid variable names
valid_name <- 1
validName <- 2
valid.name <- 3
.hidden <- 4

# Print variables
valid_name
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
validName
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 2
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
valid.name
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
.hidden
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 4
```


:::
:::




### Data Types

R has several basic data types:




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Numeric
num <- 42.5
typeof(num)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "double"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Integer (note the L suffix)
int <- 42L
typeof(int)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "integer"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Character
text <- "R programming"
typeof(text)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "character"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Logical
flag <- TRUE
typeof(flag)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "logical"
```


:::
:::




### Checking and Converting Types




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Check if a variable is of a specific type
is.numeric(num)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
is.character(text)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Convert between types
as.character(num)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "42.5"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
as.numeric("100")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 100
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
as.logical(1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::
:::




### Variable Information




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Get information about a variable
x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
class(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "numeric"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
length(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 5
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
str(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 num [1:5] 1 2 3 4 5
```


:::
:::




Remember that R is dynamically typed, so variables can change types during execution. This flexibility is one of R's strengths for data analysis.
